text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with turkey gravy with porcini
mushrooms and marsala this is a
make-ahead turkey gravy that's going to
make your Thanksgiving a lot easier
because if you have the sauce ready
ahead of time much more relaxed when the
turkey comes out of the oven cuz you're
not scrambling trying to make a gravy so
I like making my sauce ahead of time and
here's how I do it I get a package of
turkey necks at the store and I'm going
to brown that in a little bit of oil
over medium-high heat on both sides very
well once the turkey necks are browned
I'm going to add my mirepoix celery
carrots onions and let that cook until
it softens and the onions get a little
bit translucent and a little bit golden
brown it's going to take maybe five or
six more minutes at that point we're
going to deglaze with some wine now I'm
using Marsala wine it's kind of a sweet
wine so this sauce does definitely have
a sweet profile if you tend not to like
sweeter things use a regular dry white
wine it will be just as delicious and
don't ever use anything called cooking
wine horrible stuff don't touch it
I'm going to raise the heat to high and
we're going to boil that until it
reduces by about half and this is not
scientific you just look in you're
looking you're like you know what looks
like about half gone you can even go
down a little farther than that but just
don't let it evaporate and burn at that
point I'm going to add my cold water
couple quarts I'm also going to add a
bay leaf a couple peeled garlic cloves
and a little bit of dry porcini maybe a
quarter of an ounce all right we're
going to give that a stir and we're
going to bring it up to a simmer now
remember we're still on high heat here
but as soon as it does come to a simmer
I want you to back it down to low so you
just have a nice gentle simmer going
alright and of course as it comes up to
a simmer you can skim any foam that
comes to the top and once you've
adjusted your flame just right and you
have just that nice nice gentle simmer
going there we're going to cover but not
all the way
leave it cracked about an inch and we're
going to slowly slowly simmer that on
low heat for about four or five hours
I need that meat to fall right off those
neck bones I want all that flavor going
into the broth all right the meat should
be completely flavorless and bland
everything's been extracted into the
liquid all right so when you're happy
with it I want you to strain it
carefully transfer it into a container
and let it cool completely you're
probably going to have a quart in half
so set that aside if it cools down all
the way you can just refrigerate it
until needed you can totally make the
stock a day ahead no problem to finish
the sauce I'm going to take another
handful of mushrooms another maybe
quarter ounce I'm going to soak it in
some warm water for about 15 minutes so
it's soft enough to dice I'm going to
pull it out I'm going to squeeze it by
the way you can save that liquid if you
want be careful there might be sand at
the bottom but if you want to thin your
sauce later with a little bit of that
you can and we're going to take those
rehydrated porcini mushrooms dice them
very fine and then with a little bit of
butter in a sauce pan we're going to
brown those over medium heat until
really nicely caramelized this is where
a lot of the flavors coming from all
right it'll almost look like bacon bits
just gorgeous and the smell of this is
just otherworldly I can't even describe
it well actually I just did otherworldly
so amazing your neighbors will be like
what the hell's going on over there all
right at that point I'm going to dump in
some flour and we're going to make a
little bit of a roux that's going to
thicken this gravy and I keep saying
gravy it is really more of a sauce I'm
gonna stir in the flour and over medium
heat we're going to cook that flour for
about three minutes and then you guessed
it we're going to whisk in slowly at
first we're going to whisk in our turkey
neck stock all right once the first cup
or so is in you can just dump it all in
at that point you can raise your heat up
to medium-high and let's bring that up
to a simmer now this is going to reduce
down I'm hoping to end up with just
under a quart of sauce so it's not going
to be that thick when you first start
reducing it but as you'll see after a
couple cups of water our evaporated up
out of there it will thicken up
beautifully so just keep an eye on it
you can reduce it slow on a lower heat
you can turn yours to medium high like I
did here reduce it a little quicker just
be careful you don't want to do all that
work in them you know burn it so I
suggest using medium heat and just
boiling it down until you're perfectly
happy with the texture which I was right
there and like I said earlier not as
thick as a gravy much more like a
classic restaurant style sauce
consistency and yeah
us you don't have to waste the pan
juices from your turkey you could pour
that off boil it down and add it right
to this so that's not a problem but like
I said at the beginning it's just so
much easier having your gravy made ahead
of time all right final stage we're
going to do little seasoning which is
going to be freshly ground black pepper
a good amount big pinch of salt of
course that's to taste and just a little
drizzle of cream to give it a little
extra richness it is a holiday after all
and it also really makes for a beautiful
color I'm going to transfer that into my
gravy boat and then I suggest you pour
it over roast turkey mashed potatoes
stuffing etc just incredibly delicious
so anyway there you go turkey gravy with
porcini mushrooms and Marsala wine I
hope you give this a try I think you're
going to love it head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts as usual and as always enjoy
